1577754529_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:
> ...So therefore you only need to work on the quality of your simulations.

You need a quality simulation, and a judge that can tell the AI what is good and bad, known as the objective function. Implementing a good objective function is nearly impossible, as the real world is hopelessly complicated, and any AI that's smart enough will typically find a way to trick the objective function into thinking it is doing something good. When it comes to superintellegences, not even humans are good enough objective functions, as the AI will do something you don't like the moment look away, and it will be smart enough that you will never find out.
If anyone is interested, I uploaded a video on KopyKate from coputerphile about AI [here](http://127.0.0.1:43110/big.kopykate.bit/?Video=1577763081_1CJc7iRKb8yncAkdF29t1M85mhfYEKgAFj).

1578689237_12BRJSQrTETJVZzt2jHdqPywv3Sdu.body: What's probably more concerning for the desktop is Google Stadia and Chromebooks trying to move all of the computation power to "the cloud" and away from the users. If Google Stadia ever becomes viable and pc gamers migrate to it, it could end powerful consumer hardware for good. After all, why buy a $1000 desktop pc when you can just play games for "free" on "the cloud".

1579514127_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body: The way I see it, programming isn't about being able to memorize every single library function out there, but about being able use libraries and the language's syntax to make a working program. Googling while programming is absolutely ok, especially when you're using libraries or languages you're unfamiliar with.

1580721027_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUt.body: The main issue with modern copyright is that only corporate machines can afford to enforce it in lengthy court cases, while the small content creator is powerless to protect their work. Corporate machines have further bastardized copyright by extending it past of death of the original creator, leading only to more benefits for companies and none for individuals.

> [sfs9](#comment_35_1Ev2p6pn33TkPNNrMbNFwSspPzivpKaTKD): ... How about using the word "nazism" for something that has a positive meaning? ...

You have a point, communism has a negative connotation to many people, so using it to advertise networks like BitTorrent and ZeroNet may be ill informed. Besides, in these communities no one "owns" content as it is stored on many different people's computers and accessible and copy-able by everyone for no cost and with free software.

> [blurhy](#comment_345_1JcHMiQxXHX9q3ZK2LF9rZjvg3MUtTpcK): Interestingly, with p2p networks, corporate machines can do nothing too.

If networks like ZeroNet ever take off, corporations will likely make an attempt to coral people into advertising hellholes along the lines of facebook and twitter. They won't and can't, however stop small creators from making their own independent sites, and there will be less incentive to advertise on these sites due to free hosting.

1582788975_19NNH1RF6TRJUjp1qpT7Ri6opWw5y.body:
> [32767](#comment_8_1CQXqzcFLdzbuFCAeBSprGqn8nvZpHyySR): ...ZN should implement a blacklist, or a shadowban system to help them keep their ignorant worldview to themselves.

ZeroNet should not implement such a system. A global centralized blocklist would lead to people being muted for their political beliefs and to all of the anonymous accounts being muted. nofish could also receive bribes from companies or governments to silence individual users. If you don't want to see such users, use a blocklist or mute them yourself.
